awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of technology that can produce large torque without gear systems and with a higher efficiency than existing systems. From drills (small) to escalators (large), most high-torque products require gear systems to amplify the torque given the maximum capacity because the size of the product cannot be increased or decreased indefinitely. However, it is known that gear systems reduce efficiency by as much as 80%. Also, due to irregular loading utility, it experiences vibration and counter torque affecting the motor's life. Moreover, mobile systems requiring huge input power mostly rely on fossil fuels that pollute the environment. The proposed technology is anticipated to affect the electric motor market, especially high torque motors, and it will provide opportunities to form new markets that have not been explored due to the limited efficiency of motors.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a sustainable torque generator which is developed by utilizing multiple Control Moment Gyroscopes that can generate huge gyroscopic torque. However, since the torque generated by the Control Moment Gyroscopes is uncoordinated, singular, and non-permanent, it is difficult to make the Control Moment Gyroscopes a motor system that can generate torque in a constant direction. Nevertheless, by optimizing the configuration of multiple Control Moment Gyroscopes with this mechanism and developing the proprietary control algorithm, this solution can produce large torque without gear systems with higher efficiency than existing systems. This project will challenge the usage of the conventional motor and engine system and establish the benefits of a new gyroscopic effect-driven gearless torque generator.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The main goal of this project was to participate in the National I-Corps Teams program to explore the market potential for a new torque-generating technology. Through the program, we aimed to identify potential customers, understand market needs, and analyze the customer ecosystem in industries that require high-torque solutions, such as manufacturing, energy, and transportation. By conducting in-depth interviews with engineers, planners, and other stakeholders, we gained valuable insights into how the technology could address key industry challenges, particularly around improving energy efficiency and reducing operational costs.


The I-Corps program provided important feedback that helped refine the direction of the technology. By pinpointing specific challenges in the target sectors, such as the demand for more efficient and reliable torque generation, we were able to better align the technology with real-world needs. This insight was crucial for mapping out a path toward commercialization and considering potential partnerships with key players in the industry.


While the focus was primarily on customer discovery, the project also resulted in the development of a torque generator prototype, which exceeded the initial scope. We demonstrated the prototype during live sessions with potential industry partners, under Non-Disclosure Agreements (NDAs), which helped showcase its capabilities and potential for commercialization. The prototype served as a tangible proof of concept, generating interest from stakeholders and opening the door for future collaborations.


The project also contributed to the broader entrepreneurial ecosystem, leading to the creation of a startup aimed at bringing the technology to market. With the insights from the I-Corps program and the prototype development, the next steps will focus on pursuing Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) and Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) funding to support further development and deployment.


In conclusion, the project successfully identified market needs, developed a proof of concept, and moved closer to commercialization. It helped bridge academic research with practical applications, contributing to technology transfer and innovation. The ongoing commercialization efforts and further development of the technology are expected to have a significant impact on industries that demand high-torque solutions, driving efficiency and reducing costs across these sectors.


Last Modified: 12/23/2024
Modified by: Donghoon Kim
